#Text=Know if a Pet Mouse Is Right for You
#Text=You ’ve seen those little balls of fur running around with their big eyes and twitching noses at the pet store and wondered what it would be like to have a pet mouse .
#Text=Mice are highly intelligent and social creatures that can make rewarding first pets or furry new additions to your home at any age .
#Text=Despite their small size , mice are a big responsibility , as is any pet that depends on you for survival .
#Text=Soon enough you ’ll know if you ’re ready to pick out a mouse !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Seeing if You Have the Resources
#Text=Learn about the basics of providing a healthy home for mice .
#Text=Although mice are generally independent and easy to maintain , they do require a certain amount of care and attention .
#Text=Healthy mice need the basics of a varied diet , cleanliness , and plenty of exercise .
#Text=Mice are very intelligent and active animals so keep in mind that you will need to provide them with adequate space , chew toys , and an exercise wheel to keep them healthy and happy .
#Text=Decide if you can care for at least two mice .
#Text=Mice are by nature social animals , so it is recommended to get at least two that can live together , with a female-female pair being the best option .
#Text=Mice reproduce very rapidly , so it is not recommended to house males and females together .
#Text=Male mice may display aggressive behavior and fight if housed together .
#Text=See if you have space for a cage or aquarium of at least two cubic feet .
#Text=Mice may be small , but the more space you give them in their captivity the better as they are very active little creatures .
#Text=It is recommended to house mice in a space that allows them at least one cubic foot of space each .
#Text=Mice are nocturnal creatures who are sensitive to heat and light .
#Text=Make sure that you have a space for their cage or aquarium that stays out of direct sunlight and away from strong heat sources .
#Text=If you have other pets such as dogs or cats , or small children , make sure that you have a safe space out of their reach to house your mice to avoid any unfortunate accidents .
#Text=Determine if you have the budget to cover initial and ongoing costs .
#Text=Compared to other larger animals , owning a pet mouse is much cheaper , however it is not free .
#Text=There will be initial expenses to purchase housing , toys , bedding and food as well as ongoing expenses .
#Text=Keep in mind that you will probably spend a few hundred dollars a year on food and bedding for your pet mice .
#Text=Find a veterinarian near you that offers care for mice .
#Text=Call around to different vets in your area and ask about their experience dealing with mice .
#Text=Vets generally deal a lot more with larger more common pets , so it is important to make sure you know where to take your mice if they fall ill .
#Text=Vets that advertise services for exotic pets are more likely to have experience with mice .
#Text=Taking Your Lifestyle into Account
#Text=Choose a mouse if you want a low-maintenance pet full of personality .
#Text=Mice are intelligent and social creatures who can learn to recognize their owners and enjoy interacting with them .
#Text=Despite their small size , mice have their own quirks and personalities and can make a great alternative pet to a dog or cat .
#Text=Mice also make great first pets for children as they are relatively easy to care for and will help teach children responsibility and what it takes to raise an animal .
#Text=Be sure you have enough time to dedicate to caring for mice .

#Text=Although mice require much less time commitment than many other pets , they do benefit from regular handling and interaction with their owners , especially if you want to form a strong bond with them .
#Text=Plan to spend at least 30 minutes to an hour a day caring for your mice , and cleaning their cage out thoroughly at least once a week .
#Text=If you are planning on getting pet mice for your children , recognize that it is very likely you will still have to contribute a certain amount of your time to help care for them .
#Text=Talk with anyone else who will be caring for the mice with you .
#Text=If other people in your household will be responsible for caring for the mice as well , make sure that everyone knows the level of commitment it takes and is ready for it .

#Text=It may be tempting to give into the pleas of a child and purchase a mouse or two impulsively , but before doing this sit down and make sure they really know what it will take to care for a pet mouse .
#Text=Determine if you will be able to take care of mice for up to 3 years .
#Text=Mice live an average of 1.5-3 years , a relatively short lifespan but still a commitment .
#Text=Think about your plans for the next few years , if there is a chance of you moving , think about whether you would be able to take your furry companion with you or not .
#Text=If you have young children also consider the emotional impact of the inevitable death of their pet .
#Text=Make a plan for where to take your mice if you go on vacation .
#Text=Make sure you have a friend or find a pet boarding service that will be able to take care of your mice for a few days in the event of your absence .
#Text=Warning
#Text=Mice carry a very small risk of salmonella and are not recommended as pets for people with weakened immune systems , pregnant women , or children under the age of 5 .
